Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor D. Tyler McQuade of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Florida State University will develop new synthetic methods by creating (1) stereoconvergent allylic substitutions, providing the same stereoisomer for both cis and trans substrates; (2) catalyst-controlled reactivity where neighboring stereocenters have limited impact on diastereoselectivity; and (3) regiocontrolled catalytic hydroborations. As rare metals such as rhodium and iridium become more expensive, it is critically important to increase the range of reactions that can be performed by inexpensive metals such as copper. The resulting methods could be more efficient and selective than prior reactions and could enable new strategies to construct valuable complex molecules from less expensive metals, providing the basic science necessary to improve sustainability.

The proposed work is predicted to result in not only a more thorough understanding of catalysts that provide greater chemical control but also the creation of promising new synthetic methods. The successful results of this work will positively impact the pharmaceutical, agrochemical and specialty chemical industries. In addition, this project will provide excellent training of students, from undergraduate to post-doctoral, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences. These students will become the vanguard, leading the way into a future of more environmentally-friendly and internationally-competitive organic chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this NSF project was to expand the application of earth-abundant copper(I) catalysts in order to develop new synthetic organic transformations enabling the efficient construction of more complex structures. We have also pushed forward into using flow chemistry to prepare and use some of the catalysts discovered (Figure 1).

We have developed a number of new chemical reactions during this period of performance. These reactions have been well received by the community and have resulted in a number of other researchers worldwide requesting some of our catalysts to attempt their reactions or in some cases other researchers have prepared our catalyst independently and used them to realize other new reactions. The most exciting aspect of others adopting our work demonstrates that our group's approach has yielded valuable and reproducible results.

We have realized a new reaction approach that we refer to as "Ate-Mediated Allylic Substitution (AMAS)." This method enables rapid construction of linear carbon fragments. We predict that this new method will benefit both academic and industrial researchers produce molecular solutions to important problems.

One of the most important objectives of this research effort was to define the mechanism of  Cu(I)-mediate allylic substitutions. These reactions are widely used but the mechanism is not understood. The limited mechanistic understanding prevents new Cu(I) chemistry from being developed rapidly. We have developed an entirely new mechanistic hypothesis based on the results of our efforts during this project. A range of reactions, aided by theoretical calculations, have been performed to establish or disprove specific reaction pathways. These efforts afforded better understanding of the possible mechanism for these catalytic reactions.

This award provided research training support to two postdoctoral researchers (one of them femaile) and five graduate students (two of them females). The young researchers were trained in the synthetic organic chemistry and catalytic conversions, NMR spectroscopy and X-ray crystallography, and theoretical methods of electronic structure analysis. Two of the students have completed their PhD studies and another two are nearing the completion of the PhD theses.

Overall, this NSF project has yielded a wide variety of outstanding research results. We feel strongly that this body of work provides clear evidence that earth-abudant metal such as copper can catalyze a rich suite of organic reactions. We have applied some of the knowledge gained on the reaction chemistry side to development of a number of potential useful bioprobes. One example is our new fructose analogs that might be used to understand fuctose fate and metabolism in organisms.

Modified by: Mykhailo Shatruk
